title: India's challenge in a globalizing healthcare economy: social science directions
abstractText:
India will be the third largest economy in the world by 2020. Healthcare is one of the largest sectors in terms of revenue and employment, and is expanding rapidly. But despite rapid economic growth there are great social and economic inequalities.

The complex relationship between India's adaptation to the new global environment and Indian population heath needs and aspirations, local and international health systems, and healthcare related industries, is one that social scientists are beginning to study.

The network proposes to strengthen and extend this activity by:

  • Bringing together and examining the diverse literatures.
  • Hosting workshops in London and New Delhi to enable key researchers from across the social sciences in India and the UK, and potential users of their work,  to come together to discuss existing findings, emerging topic areas, and the new methods that may be required for investigating these. 
  • Publishing findings as Open Access papers in a journal special issue.
  • Developing future research priorities.

The network is coordinated by researchers from three key universities which bring together interests in social science, healthcare and health policy, globalization, and India  -  King's College London, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, and London School of Economics and Political Science.

findingsText:
Outputs from the network project are: 1) Review paper on 'India, Globalisation and Healthcare', by Drs Bisht, Murray and Pitchforth, which identifies seven broad thematic areas of study, highlights a young and expanding literature, and a clear need for greater social science contributions in this field that go beyond commentaries and descriptive overviews. 2) An independently peer-reviewed Social Sciences Special Issue of the open access journal 'Globalization and Health', entitled 'Health systems, health economies and globalisation: social science perspectives'. Much of the material in the review and specialist papers is relevant to health policy, and well as to the general societal understanding of current developments in healthcare and health policy. The special issue series of papers give an overview and specific detailed insights into key issues concerning contemporary globalization and health, written from a range of social science perspectives.
